pages.text: In order to progress, we'll need to work metal. But before we can do that, we need $(item)Flux$(), which is used to weld items together. Flux is made from any of the fluxstones: $(thing)Chalk, Dolomite, Limestone, and Marble.$()
In order to make flux or use an anvil, you'll need a $(item)hammer.

pages.title: Flux
pages.text: To make flux, just craft your hammer with one of the fluxstones outlined earlier. If you find the mineral $(item)borax$(), you can crush it in a $(l:processes/quern)quern$() to make flux.

The first kind of anvil you'll use is the stone anvil. To make one, you need to right click with your hammer on an exposed raw $(thing)igneous$() rock. The igneous rocks are $(thing)Diorite, Gabbro, Granite, Andesite, Basalt, Dacite, and Rhyolite.
The stone anvil is the most basic anvil in the game.
pages.name: Stone Anvil

pages.text: In order to get something to work in the anvil, you'll need ingots. Luckily, that's easy! You'll need 100 units of any metal or alloy, and pour it into the $(l:basic_smithing/casting)ceramic ingot mold.$()
insert ingot mold knapping recipe here

Anvils can be used to shape metal into all sorts of things, but for our purposes, we're just going to worry about $(thing)welding$() for now. In order to weld something, it needs to be at a workable temperature. When something comes out of an ingot mold at first, it should say $(item)Can Work$() and/or $(item)Can Weld$(). You can also use your forge to heat things up to these temperatures.

The longer something stays out of the forge, the more it cools, so you have to work fast. Open the anvil GUI and place your $(item)flux$() inside. Then, place an ingot in both left side slots. Exit the GUI and shift+right click to weld the ingots. This will give you a $(item)double ingot$()
This is just the copper anvil, which will enable to you work on copper items, but this recipe works for any of the main tool metals!
